channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: Prosecutors rest their case in trial of man accused in attempted Trump assassination
item.description: Ryan Routh is on trial for plotting to kill President Trump, while he golfed at his Florida course last year during the election campaign. Prosecutors wrapped up their arguments Friday.

item.title: The White House wants to fast track its rescission of some national forest rules
item.description: The U.S. Forest Service is trying to fast track the rescission of the 2001 Roadless Rule, which banned logging and new roadbuilding in 58 million acres of national forests. But it won't be easy.

item.title: Hanging death of a student in Mississippi is officially ruled a suicide
item.description: A hanging death of a student in Mississippi this week fueled online speculations hat is was a lynching. It was officially ruled a suicide Friday.

item.title: Meet the couple who have performed karaoke almost every night for 25 years
item.description: Bob and Patti Vasconcellos have gone to a local karaoke bar to sing almost every night for decades. Now in their late 70s and early 80s, they hit the floor with their walkers, and the crowd goes wild.

item.title: Ace pitcher Clayton Kershaw announced his retirement at the end of the season
item.description: The legendary pitcher will be stepping onto the mound Friday night, but it will be bittersweet for Dodgers fans. After almost two decades, he announced he'll be retiring after this season.

item.title: Sarah McLachlan has a new album for the first time in over a decade
item.description: Singer-songwriter Sarah McLachlan has released a new album for the first time in over a decade. It arrives alongside a new documentary about the Lilith Fair music festival she founded.

item.title: Where could the U.S. government restrict free speech?
item.description: NPR's Ailsa Chang speaks with University of Pennsylvania law professor Amanda Shanor about free speech protections in the wake of the killing of Charlie Kirk.

item.title: A congressman called Charlie Kirk Jesus's '13th disciple.' Other Christians disagree
item.description: Charlie Kirk's evangelical followers frame him as a martyr for free speech. But they are facing fierce counter-arguments from other Christians, particularly African-Americans.

item.title: Social video and podcasts are the next frontier for Democrats seeking office
item.description: Some political strategists say Democrats are falling behind Republicans in reaching voters in an important way: They're not active enough on platforms like TikTok.

item.title: House passes spending bill but shutdown threat still looms
item.description: The government appeared to inch closer to a shutdown on Friday after a short-term spending bill cleared by the House was blocked in the Senate amid a broader fight over expiring health care subsidies.
